citations.narrative:
On April 15, 2025, one of two pigeons in an outdoor aviary escaped its enclosure when a student entered to retrieve a
pigeon for a laboratory procedure. The pigeon flew away and was not returned to safety.
Enclosures that do not have additional security measures are ineffective in protecting against flighted bird escapes.
Escaped domesticated birds face increased dangers and challenges to their health and welfare ever present in the wild.
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Housing facilities must employ security measures that contain all
birds securely. Such measures may include safety doors, entry/exit doors to the primary enclosure that are double-door,
or other equivalent systems designed to prevent escape of the birds. Birds that are flight-restricted or cannot fly and are
allowed to roam free within the housing facility or a portion thereof must have access to safety pens, enclosures, or other
areas that offer the birds protection during overnight periods and at times when their activities are not monitored.
Correct by August 25, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility's authorized person.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
On April 15, 2025, one of two pigeons in an outdoor aviary escaped its enclosure when a student entered to retrieve a 
pigeon for a laboratory procedure. The pigeon flew away and was not returned to safety.  
 
Enclosures that do not have additional security measures are ineffective in protecting against flighted bird escapes. 
Escaped domesticated birds face increased dangers and challenges to their health and welfare ever present in the wild. 
 
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird 
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering 
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Housing facilities must employ security measures that contain all 
birds securely. Such measures may include safety doors, entry/exit doors to the primary enclosure that are double-door, 
or other equivalent systems designed to prevent escape of the birds. Birds that are flight-restricted or cannot fly and are 
allowed to roam free within the housing facility or a portion thereof must have access to safety pens, enclosures, or other 
areas that offer the birds protection during overnight periods and at times when their activities are not monitored.  
 
Correct by August 25, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility's authorized person. 
 
 n
